content.shortDefinition: The hierarchical structure of language units that make up sentences in te reo Māori.

elements.content:
In te reo Māori, sentences are constructed from hierarchical components, each building upon the smaller units to create complete thoughts. From smallest to largest, these components are:

## Hierarchy of Sentence Components

1. **[[ref\|Kupu\|kupu]] (Words)** - The smallest independent units of meaning - Includes [[ref\|tumu\|tumu]] (base words) and [[ref\|punga\|punga]] (particles) - Examples: [[word\|kai\|w-kai]] (eat), [[word\|te\|w-te]] (the), [[word\|moana\|w-moana]] (ocean)

2. **[[ref\|Kīanga\|kiianga]] (Phrases)** - Groups of related words that function as a unit but don't contain both a subject and predicate - Examples: {{te whare}} (the house), {{kei te kai}} (is eating)

3. **[[ref\|Aho\|aho]] (Clauses)** - Units containing a predicate and typically a subject - Can be [[ref\|aho motuhake\|aho-motuhake]] (main clauses) or [[ref\|aho whakawhirinaki\|aho-whakawhirinaki]] (subordinate clauses) - Example: {{Kei te kai a Mere}} (Mary is eating)

4. **[[ref\|Rerenga\|rerenga]] (Sentences)** - Complete thoughts expressed through one or more clauses - Example: {{Kei te kai a Mere i te āporo}} (Mary is eating the apple)

## Understanding with an Example

Consider the sentence: {{Ka tae ake ki te moana, ka kuhu tonu atu rātou ki te wai.}} (When they arrived at the ocean, they immediately went into the water.)

This sentence is included as an example below with a detailed breakdown you can explore using the sentence analyzer.

Understanding this hierarchical structure is essential for analyzing and constructing grammatically correct sentences in te reo Māori.

content.shortDefinition: Words that convey the core meaning of a sentence in te reo Māori.

elements.content:
In te reo Māori, words are typically classified as either tumu (bases) or [[ref\|punga\|punga]] (particles). These are essential word categories to understand when considering [[ref\|phrases\|kianga]] because a phrase is made up of a base surrounded by optional particles.

Tumu (base words) convey the core meaning of the sentence and are also known as "kupu kiko" or "content words." They are the essential building blocks that carry the main information in communication.

Base words include:

* [[ref\|Tūingoa\|tuuingoa]] (nouns) - Words referring to things, people, animals, or ideas
* [[ref\|Tūmahi\|tuumahi]] (verbs) - Words describing actions or states of being

For example, in the sentence {{Kei te kai au i te āporo}} (I am eating the apple),\
the words [[word\|kai\|w-kai]] (eat), [[word\|au\|w-au]] (I), and [[word\|āporo\|w-aaporo]] (apple) are {{tumu}}—they provide the key information about **who** is doing what **to** what. The other words are particles that provide grammatical structure.

elements.maori: Kei te ako au i te reo Māori.
elements.english: I am learning te reo Māori.
elements.explanation: The base words (tumu) are [[word|ako|w-ako]] (learn), [[word|au|w-au]] (I), and {{reo Māori}} (Māori language).

elements.maori: Ka haere tātou ki te moana āpōpō.
elements.english: We will go to the beach tomorrow.
elements.explanation: The base words are [[word|haere|w-haere]] (go), [[word|tātou|w-taatou]] (we), [[word|moana|w-moana]] (beach/sea), and [[word|āpōpō|w-aapoopoo]] (tomorrow).

content.shortDefinition: Small words that provide grammatical information and context in te reo Māori sentences.

elements.content:
Punga (particles) are small but crucial elements in te reo Māori grammar. Unlike tumu (base words) which carry the core meaning, particles provide grammatical structure, context, and additional information about how the base words relate to each other. Particles typically come before or after a base word and help to: - Indicate tense, aspect, and mood 
* Show relationships between words 
* Mark location or direction 
* Identify possession 
* Structure questions 
* Link parts of sentences together The main types of particles include: 
1. [[ref\|Pūmahi\|pumahi]] (verbal particles) - Words like "ka," "kua," "i," "e...ana," and "kei te" that indicate when an action occurs and how it unfolds 
2. [[ref\|Pūwāhi\|puuwaahi]] (locative particles) - Words like "i," "hei," and "kei" used with locations 
3. [[ref\|Pūanga\|puuanga]] (directional particles) - Words like "mai," "atu," "ake," and "iho" that show direction 
4. [[ref\|Pūhea\|puuhea]] (positional particles) - Words like "nei," "nā," and "rā" that show proximity 
5. [[ref\|Pūingoa\|puingoa]] (nominal particles) - Words like "te," "ngā," "he," "a," and "o" that introduce nouns 
6. [[ref\|Pūriro\|puriro]] (possessive particles) - Words like "tā," "tō," "ā," and "ō" that indicate possession

elements.maori: Kei te kai a Mere i te āporo.
elements.explanation: Particles include: "kei te" (present continuous marker), "a" (personal article), "i" (object marker), and "te" (definite article).

elements.maori: I haere atu rātou ki te tāone inanahi.
elements.explanation: Particles include: "i" (past tense marker), "atu" (directional particle meaning "away"), "ki" (directional particle), and "te" (definite article).

content.shortDefinition: Words that name people, places, things, animals, or abstract concepts in te reo Māori.
content.label: noun

elements.content:
Nouns are the words we use to describe things, people, animals and ideas. They are the words we use for naming things. Nouns are sometimes separated into:

* {{tūingoa ōkiko}} (concrete nouns) for material things like cats, trees, tables
* {{tūingoa tūrehurehu}} (abstract nouns) for intangible things like ideas, emotions, concepts
* {{tūmoko}} (proper nouns) for names of people, places, iwi, waka and the months

elements.maori: Kei te oma te kurī.
elements.explanation: The noun "kurī" (dog) is a tūingoa ōkiko (concrete noun) functioning as the subject of the sentence.

elements.maori: He tino nui tō rātou aroha ki te whenua.
elements.english: Their love for the land is very great.
elements.explanation: The nouns "aroha" (love) and "whenua" (land) represent a tūingoa tūrehurehu (abstract noun) and a tūingoa ōkiko (concrete noun) respectively.

elements.maori: I haere a Mere ki Tāmaki Makaurau inanahi.
elements.explanation: The words "Mere" (Mary) and "Tāmaki Makaurau" (Auckland) are tūmoko (proper nouns) for a person and a place.

content.shortDefinition: Special nouns that indicate position or location in space relative to a reference point.

elements.content:
Tūwāhi (locative nouns) are a special class of nouns in te reo Māori that specify location or position in space. They describe where something is in relation to a reference point, such as above, below, inside, or outside. Unlike regular nouns, locative nouns typically appear in [[ref\|prepositional phrases\|kiianga-puuhono]] and are usually preceded by [[ref\|particles\|punga]] such as "i," "ki," or "kei" to form expressions of location. Common locative nouns include:

* runga - on top, above, south

* raro - under, underneath, below, north

* roto - in, inside

* waho - out, outside

* mua - in front, at the front, before

* muri - behind, at the back

* waenganui <noun 1> i <noun 2> (optional me <noun 3>) - in the middle, between, among

* te taha mauī <noun 1> o <noun 2> - on the left side of noun 2

* te taha matau <noun 1> o <noun 2> - on the right side of noun 2

* tua - beyond, the other side (of a solid object)

* tāwāhi - beyond, the other side (of an open space)

* Locatives which describe somewhere in relation to the speaker/writer:

*  uta - ashore (while at sea), inland (while on the coast)

* tai - at sea (while on shore), on the coast (while inland)

* tawhiti - in the distance

* konei - here (where I am, in this place)

* konā - there (where you are, in that place)

* korā, kō - there (away from us, in that other place)

* reira - there (in that place we've been talking about)

elements.maori: Kei runga i te tēpu te pukapuka.
elements.english: The book is on top of the table.
elements.explanation: The locative noun "runga" indicates the position (on top) relative to the reference object (the table).

elements.maori: I haere ia ki roto i te whare.
elements.explanation: The locative noun "roto" indicates movement to the interior of the reference object (the house).

elements.maori: Kei muri i a koe te kurī.
elements.explanation: The locative noun "muri" indicates position (behind) relative to the reference point (you).

elements.maori: Kei konei tātou e hui ana.
elements.explanation: The locative noun "konei" indicates the location where the speaker is currently situated.

content.shortDefinition: Words that substitute for nouns or noun phrases, conveying person, number, and inclusivity/exclusivity.

elements.content:
Pronouns are words such as "he", "she" or "them" that take the place of nouns or noun phrases. Tūkapi (pronouns) in te reo Māori are an important class of [[ref\|tumu\|tumu]] (base words) that communicate a significant amount of contextual information within a compact form. They convey different information than those in English.

They distinguish:

1. Person - Whether you're talking about:

* {{Kiritūnei}} (first person) - the speaker - "I/we"
* {{Kiritūnei}} (second person) - the listener - "you"
* {{Kiritūrā}} (third person) - someone else - "he/she/they"

2. Number - Whether you're referring to:

* {{Takitahi}} (singular) - one person
* {{Takirua}} (dual) - two people
* {{Takitini}} (plural) - three or more people

3. Inclusivity/Exclusivity: For first person dual and plural, whether:

* {{Kauawhi}} (inclusive) - including the listener ("you and I"/"you and us")
* {{Kaupare}} (exclusive) - excluding the listener ("someone else and I"/"others and I")

Using these terms to create the reo Māori term for the first person exclusive dual pronoun as an example would give you: {{tūkapi kaupare kiritūnei takirua}}.

This creates a more detailed pronoun system than in English. The full set of personal pronouns is:

|  | takitahi (singular) | takirua (dual) | takitini (plural) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| tūkapi kauawhi kiritūnei *first person inclusive pronoun* |  | [[word\|tāua\|w-taaua]] | [[word\|tātou\|w-taatou]] |
| tūkapi kaupare kiritūnei *first person exclusive pronoun* | [[word\|au\|w-au]], [[word\|ahau\|w-ahau]] | [[word\|māua\|w-maaua]] | [[word\|mātou\|w-maatou]] |
| tūkapi kiritūnā second person pronoun | [[word\|koe\|w-koe]] | [[word\|kōrua\|w-koorua]] | [[word\|koutou\|w-koutou]] |
| tūkapi kiritūrā third person pronoun | [[word\|ia\|w-ia]] | [[word\|rāua\|w-raaua]] | [[word\|rātou\|w-raatou]] |

elements.maori: Kei te haere au ki te kura.
elements.explanation: The pronoun "au" is first person singular (I).

elements.maori: Kei hea kōrua?
elements.explanation: The pronoun "kōrua" is second person dual (you two).

elements.maori: Ka haere tātou ki te hui.
elements.english: We (including you) will go to the meeting.
elements.explanation: The pronoun "tātou" is first person plural inclusive, meaning "we" including the person being spoken to.

elements.maori: Ka haere mātou ki te hui.
elements.english: We (not including you) will go to the meeting.
elements.explanation: The pronoun "mātou" is first person plural exclusive, meaning "we" excluding the person being spoken to.

elements.content:
## Demonstrative Pronouns

There is a subclass of pronouns formed when we use the [[ref\|T-Class Determiners\|t-class-determiners]] in the position of a pronoun.

content.shortDefinition: Possessive pronouns are used to replace nouns when describing possessive relationships.

elements.content:
If we want to say that something is owned by something else but refer to the owner using a pronoun, we can use a {{tūkapi riro}} (possessive pronoun) which we form by prepending a {{pūriro}} (possessive particle) to a [[ref|tūkapi|tukapi]] (pronoun). The singular tūkapi take a special form when use in this way: * {{au}} becomes the suffix {{-ku}} * {{koe}} becomes the suffix {{-u}} * {{ia}} becomes the suffix {{-na}} For each pronoun, I’ll list out the {{tūkapi riro takitahi}} (singular possessive pronouns) and the {{tūkapi riro takitini}} (plural possessive pronouns). Each possessive pronoun has multiple forms which include information about the nature of the possessive relationship using the A/O categories which are explained more in [[ref|a/o categories|a-o-categories]]. | tūkapi | type of tūkapi | tūkapi riro takitahi | tūkapi riro takitini| | :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- | | [[word|au|w-au]] | tūkapi kiritūnei takitahi
(singular first person pronoun) | [[word|taku|w-taku]], [[word|tāku|w-taaku]], [[word|tōku|w-tooku]] | [[word|aku|w-aku]], [[word|āku|w-aaku]], [[word|ōku|w-ooku]] | | [[word|koe|w-koe]] | tūkapi kiritūnā takitahi
(singular second person pronoun) | [[word|tō|w-too]], [[word|tāu|w-taau]], [[word|tōu|w-toou]] | [[word|ō|w-oo]], [[word|āu|w-aau]], [[word|ōu|w-oou]] | | [[word|ia|w-ia]] | tūkapi kiritūrā takitahi
(singular third person pronoun) | [[word|tana|w-tana]], [[word|tāna|w-taana]], [[word|tōna|w-toona]] | [[word|ana|w-ana]], [[word|āna|w-aana]], [[word|ōna|w-oona]] | | [[word|māua|w-maaua]] | tūkapi kaupare kiritūnei takirua
(dual first person exclusive pronoun) | [[word|tā māua|w-taa-maaua]], [[word|tō māua|w-too-maaua]] | [[word|ā māua|w-aa-maaua]], [[word|ō māua|w-oo-maaua]] | | [[word|tāua|w-taaua]] | tūkapi kauawhi kiritūnei takirua
(dual first person inclusive pronoun) | [[word|tā tāua|w-taa-taaua]], [[word|tō tāua|w-too-taaua]] | [[word|ā tāua|w-aa-taaua]], [[word|ō tāua|w-oo-taaua]] | | [[word|kōrua|w-koorua]] | tūkapi kiritūnā takirua
(dual second person pronoun) | [[word|tā kōrua|w-taa-koorua]], [[word|tō kōrua|w-too-koorua]] | [[word|ā kōrua|w-aa-koorua]], [[word|ō kōrua|w-oo-koorua]] | | [[word|rāua|w-raaua]] | tūkapi kiritūrā takirua

(plural first person exclusive pronoun) | [[word|tā mātou|w-taa-maatou]], [[word|tō mātou|w-too-maatou]] | [[word|ā mātou|w-aa-maatou]], [[word|ō mātou|w-oo-maatou]] | | [[word|tātou|w-taatou]] | tūkapi kauawhi kiritūnei takitini
(plural first person inclusive pronoun) | [[word|tā tātou|w-taa-taatou]], [[word|tō tātou|w-too-taatou]] | [[word|ā tātou|w-aa-taatou]], [[word|ō tātou|w-oo-taatou]] | | [[word|koutou|w-koutou]] | tūkapi kiritūnā takitini
(plural second person pronoun) | [[word|tā koutou|w-taa-koutou]], [[word|tō koutou|w-too-koutou]] | [[word|ā koutou|w-aa-koutou]], [[word|ō koutou|w-oo-koutou]] | | [[word|rātou|w-raatou]] | tūkapi kiritūrā takitini
(plural third person pronoun) | [[word|tā rātou|w-taa-raatou]], [[word|tō rātou|w-too-raatou]] | [[word|ā rātou|w-aa-raatou]], [[word|ō rātou|w-oo-raatou]] |

These possessive pronouns have two types of "plurality": whether the thing being possessed is plural and whether the thing doing the possessing is plural. For example:
* In {{āku tamariki}} (my children) there is one of me and multiple children.
* In {{tā mātou tamaiti}} (our child) there are multiple of us and one child.

content.shortDefinition: Words that describe actions, occurrences, or states of being.
content.categoryInfo: Part of the Base Words (Tumu) series
content.longDefinition:
Tūmahi (verbs) are a fundamental type of [[ref|tumu|tumu]] (base word) in te reo Māori that express actions, occurrences, or states of being. Also known as "kupumahi," they form the core of verbal phrases and sentences.

A key characteristic of te reo Māori verbs is that, unlike English verbs, they do not change form to indicate tense, person, or number. Instead, [[ref|pūmahi|pumahi]] (verbal particles) such as "ka," "kua," "i," "e...ana," and "kei te" are used before the verb to indicate when and how the action takes place.

Te reo Māori verbs are classified into several important categories ([[ref|see Verb Classification for detailed information|verb-classification]]):

1. **[[ref|Tūmahi Whiti (Transitive Verbs)|tuumahi-whiti]]** - Describe actions that directly affect another person or thing - Take a direct object (often marked with "i") - Can be used in passive voice with special suffixes - Examples: tapahi (cut), whakapaipai (decorate), patu (hit)

2. **[[ref|Tūmahi Poro (Intransitive Verbs)|tuumahi-poro]]** - Describe actions that don't require a direct object - The action can be completed with only one participant - Examples: moe (sleep), hīkoi (walk), takoto (lie down)

3. **[[ref|Tūmahi Āhua (Stative Verbs)|tuumahi-ahua]]** - Describe emotions or attributes of people or things - Examples: pōuri (sad), riri (angry), pūhaehae (jealous)

4. **[[ref|Tūmahi Oti (Neuter Verbs)|tuumahi-oti]]** - Describe the completion of an action or a state of being - Examples: mate (die/dead), pau (be consumed), pakaru (broken)

Understanding the different classes of verbs is essential for forming grammatically 
correct sentences and for using appropriate verbal particles and constructions.
content.label: verb

examples.maori: Kei te kai a Mere i te āporo.
examples.explanation: The verb "kai" (eat) is a tūmahi whiti (transitive verb) with "i te āporo" as its direct object.
The verb "moe" (sleep) is a tūmahi poro (intransitive verb) that does not require a direct object.
The verb "pōuri" (sad) is a tūmahi āhua (stative verb) describing an emotional state.
The verb "pakaru" (broken) is a tūmahi oti (neuter verb) describing a state resulting from a completed action.

content.shortDefinition: Verbs that describe states, conditions, emotions, or qualities rather than actions.

elements.content:
These are verbs which are commonly used to describe emotions or attributes of people or things. This class includes words such as: pōuri, riri, pūhaehae.

Tūmahi āhua (stative verbs) are a distinct class of verbs in te reo Māori that describe states, conditions, emotions, or qualities rather than actions. These verbs are sometimes called "state intransitives" or "neuter verbs" in some grammars.

elements.maori: Kua pōuri a Hemi.
elements.explanation: The stative verb "pōuri" (sad) describes an emotional state that James is experiencing.

elements.maori: He māmā te kete.
elements.explanation: The stative verb "māmā" (light in weight) describes a physical quality of the basket.

elements.maori: E hiakai ana au.
elements.explanation: The stative verb "hiakai" (hungry) describes a physical state with the continuous marker "e...ana".

elements.maori: I pōuri ia i te kōrero.
elements.english: She was sad because of the news.
elements.explanation: The stative verb "pōuri" (sad) with the cause marked by "i te kōrero" (because of the news).

content.categoryInfo: Part of the series on Verbs (Tūmahi)

content.shortDefinition: Verbs that describe actions that do not affect another person or thing and do not require a direct object.

elements.content:
These are verbs that don't require a direct object (a noun, pronoun or noun phrase) to act upon. The action described by the verb can be completed with only one participant such as sneezing (tihe) or sleeping (moe). The action doesn't directly act upon anyone or anything else. This includes words such as: moe, hīkoi, takoto and whiowhio.

Tūmahi poro (intransitive verbs) form a major category of verbs in te reo Māori.\
They describe actions that do not affect another person or thing and do not require a direct object to complete their meaning. The action described by the verb can be completed with only one participant such as sneezing (tihe) or sleeping (moe). The action doesn't directly act upon anyone or anything else. This includes words such as: moe, hīkoi, takoto and whiowhio.

elements.maori: Kei te moe a Mere.
elements.explanation: The intransitive verb "moe" (sleep) describes an action that Mary does without affecting any object.

elements.maori: I kata ngā tamariki.
elements.explanation: The intransitive verb "kata" (laugh) describes an action that occurs without a direct object.

elements.maori: Kei te kōrero ia ki te kaiako.
elements.english: He is talking to the teacher.
elements.explanation: The intransitive verb "kōrero" (speak) with "ki te kaiako" as the recipient of communication, not a direct object.

elements.maori: Ka haere mātou ki te hui āpōpō.
elements.english: We will go to the meeting tomorrow.
elements.explanation: The intransitive verb "haere" (go) with a destination indicated by "ki".

content.shortDefinition: The categorization of te reo Māori verbs into different classes based on their grammatical behaviour over time.

elements.content:
Many different attempts have been made to classify the base word classes of te reo Māori, with differing philosophies on the best taxonomy to use. In particular, the behaviour of verbs is documented differently by different linguists. There are a number of verbs which behave very similarly for many purposes, but with subtle differences in how they work from a technical perspective. Some linguists have considered statives, neuter verbs and adjectives to all be one class of word. Others break them out into complex subgroups. For ease of reference these are typically grouped into three classes based on an example word that belongs to each class, you have the {{mutu}} class, the {{ora}} class and the {{haere}} class. These have been considered in different ways over time: | | mutu | haere | ora | | :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- | | Maunsell (1842) (considered this grouping tentative) | **neuter**
(the term at the time for what we now call intransitive) | **neuter**
(the term at the time for what we now call intransitive) | **neuter**
(the term at the time for what we now call intransitive) | | Williams (1862) | **participles**

content.shortDefinition: Particles that precede verbs to indicate tense, aspect, and mood in te reo Māori.
content.categoryInfo: Part of the Particles (Punga) series
content.longDefinition: These words come before or after a verb and provide information about the context in which a verb is being used. Is it happening right now? Was it happening in the past? Has it been completed or is it still ongoing? This includes the words: ka, kua, i, e … ana, kei te, i te. | Pūmahi | Name | Use | | :---- | :---- | :---- | | Kei te | Present Continious | Describes an action which is happening as we speak. | | Kāore… i te… | Present Continuous Negative | Negates a "kei te" sentence. | | I te | Past Continuous | Describes an action which was continuing in the past. | | Kāore… i te… | Past Continous Negative | Negates an "i te" sentence. Identical to negation for "kei te" and distinction must be inferred from context. | | E … ana | Continuous | Describes an action progressing and can be used to refer to the past, present or future. | | I | Past | Describes an action which is in the past and is now history. | | Kāore i | Past Negative | Negates an "i" sentence. | | Kua | Perfect | Describes an action which has taken place to arrive at the present (in the narrative) status of the object. | | Kāore ano… kia… | Perfect Negative | Negates a "kua" sentence. We add "anō" to mean that although the action hasn't happened, it is expected to. | | Ka | New Action Past New Action Present New Action Future | Ka is an inceptive marker, which means that it introduces a new action into a narrative in whatever context is already established. We are learning it as defaulting to future tense, although it is often referred to as defaulting to present tense. | | Kāore… e… | New Action Past Negative New Action Present Negative New Action Future Negative | Negates a "ka" sentence. |Pūmahi (verbal particles) are a crucial type of punga (particle) in te reo Māori that provide information about when and how an action takes place. They appear before verbs and indicate tense (when the action occurs), aspect (how the action unfolds over time), and mood (the speaker's attitude toward the action). Unlike English, where verbs change form to show tense (e.g., walk/walked/walking), te reo Māori keeps the verb form consistent and uses these particles to convey grammatical information. The main verbal particles include: 1. **Kei te** - Present continuous - Indicates an action happening right now - Example: "Kei te kai au" - "I am eating" 2. **I te** - Past continuous - Indicates an action that was happening in the past - Example: "I te kai au" - "I was eating" 3. **E ... ana** - Continuous (general) - Can refer to past, present, or future ongoing actions - Example: "E kai ana au" - "I am/was eating" 4. **I** - Simple past - Indicates a completed action in the past - Example: "I kai au" - "I ate" 5. **Kua** - Perfect aspect - Indicates a completed action with present relevance - Example: "Kua kai au" - "I have eaten" 6. **Ka** - Inceptive/narrative - Introduces a new action in a narrative; often indicates future actions - Example: "Ka kai au" - "I will eat" Each verbal particle also has a corresponding negative form, typically using "kāore" with a different particle combination: - "Kei te" → "Kāore ... i te" - "I" → "Kāore ... i" - "Kua" → "Kāore anō ... kia" - "Ka" → "Kāore ... e" Mastering verbal particles is essential for accurately expressing when actions occur and how they unfold over time in te reo Māori.

examples.maori: Kei te tuhi a Hemi i tētahi reta.
examples.explanation: The verbal particle "kei te" indicates present continuous action (happening now).

examples.maori: I haere au ki te tāone inanahi.
examples.explanation: The verbal particle "i" indicates a completed action in the past.
The verbal particle "kua" indicates a completed action with current relevance (perfect aspect).
The verbal particle "ka" indicates a future action.

examples.maori: Kāore au i te hiahia ki te haere.
examples.explanation: The negative form "kāore ... i te" negates the present continuous "kei te".

content.shortDefinition: Verbs that describe an action affecting someone or something else, requiring a direct object.

elements.content:
These are verbs which describe an interaction between the participant carrying that action out and some other person or thing. This includes words such as: tapahi, whakapaipai.

Transitive verbs can be used in either active or passive forms depending on the type of sentence or "voice" they are being used in. When used in an active sentence they are called "tūmahi hāoho" (active verbs) and when used in a passive sentence they are called "tūmahi hāngū" (passive verbs). To make an tūmahi hāoho into a tūmahi hāngū you add a special kūmuri (suffix) or whiore (tail) to the word such as in adding the suffix "-tia" to "whakapai" to get the tūmahi hāngū whakapaitia. Each tūmahi hāoho can only take a limited subset of suffixes and a dictionary is required to know which are appropriate for each word. Some tūmahi hāoho have irregular passive forms where the word is transformed more than adding a simple suffix.

\
Tūmahi whiti (transitive verbs) are a major class of verbs in te reo Māori that describe actions which affect or are directed toward another person or thing. These verbs require a direct object—someone or something that receives the action of the verb. Transitive verbs can be used in either active or passive forms depending on the type of sentence or "voice" they are being used in. When used in an active sentence they are called "tūmahi hāoho" (active verbs) and when used in a passive sentence they are called "tūmahi hāngū" (passive verbs). To make an tūmahi hāoho into a tūmahi hāngū you add a special kūmuri (suffix) or whiore (tail) to the word such as in adding the suffix "-tia" to "whakapai" to get the tūmahi hāngū whakapaitia. Each tūmahi hāoho can only take a limited subset of suffixes and a dictionary is required to know which are appropriate for each word. Some tūmahi hāoho have irregular passive forms where the word is transformed more than adding a simple suffix.

Māori has a special construction for expressing transitive actions where the second participant (patient) is indefinite and non-specific (where the listener has no information about which particular individual is involved), for example:

* Kei te ruku kōura rātou. - They are diving for crayfish. (Not a specific crayfish.)

Non-specific patients form compound verbs, so the object 'kōura' is incorporated into the verb to form the compound verb "ruku kōura" or "crayfish diving".

elements.maori: Kei te whakarongo a Pita i te waiata.
elements.english: Peter is listening to the song.
elements.explanation: The transitive verb "whakarongo" (listen) affects the direct object "waiata" (song), which is marked with "i".

elements.maori: I pānui ia i te pukapuka.
elements.explanation: The transitive verb "pānui" (read) has "pukapuka" (book) as its direct object.

elements.maori: Ka kōrerotia e Hone te reo Māori āpōpō.
elements.explanation: The passive form of the transitive verb "kōrero" (speak) is "kōrerotia", shifting focus to "te reo Māori" while marking the agent with "e".

elements.maori: Kei te whakamārama te kaiako i te tikanga.
elements.english: The teacher is explaining the meaning.
elements.explanation: The transitive verb "whakamārama" (explain) affects the direct object "tikanga" (meaning/custom).

content.shortDefinition: Words that describe or modify nouns, indicating qualities or attributes.

elements.content:
Tūāhua (adjectives) are considered by some grammars to be a category of tumu (base words) in te reo Māori that describe the qualities, attributes, or characteristics of nouns. They help to provide more detailed information about people, places, objects, or concepts. Although some authorities take the view that words such as [[word|pai|w-pai]] should be considered to be adjectives, we'll be taking the view detailed in Te Reo Māori: The Basics Explained by David Kārena-Holmes, which is that some verbs and nouns can be used adjectivally, but that it's not necessary to consider these to be adjectives.

Qualities that would be expressed as adjectives in English are expressed as [[ref|tūmahi āhua|tuumahi-ahua]] (stative verbs) or [[ref|tūingoa|tuuingoa]] (nouns) in te reo Māori.

elements.maori: Kei te mau ia i te koti whero.
elements.english: She is wearing a red coat.
elements.explanation: The adjective "whero" (red) follows the noun "koti" (coat) it modifies.

elements.maori: He tangata pai, he tangata manaaki.
elements.english: A good person is a caring person.
elements.explanation: The adjectives "pai" (good) and "manaaki" (caring) each follow the noun "tangata" (person).

elements.maori: E hiahia ana au ki te hoko i te waka hou, nui.
elements.english: I want to buy a new, big car.
elements.explanation: The adjectives "hou" (new) and "nui" (big) appear in sequence after the noun "waka" (car).

elements.maori: He tino ātaahua tēnei whare.
elements.explanation: The intensifier "tino" (very) precedes the adjective "ātaahua" (beautiful).

content.shortDefinition: Words used to form questions, such as who, what, where, when, why, and how.
content.longDefinition:
When asking for a piece of information using a rerepātai (question sentence) these words are used in the sentence in place of the piece of information you want to obtain and which word you use makes it clear what type of information you want to be supplied with. This includes the words: wai, aha, hea, hia, pēhea, tēhea.

Tūpātai (interrogatives) are a category of [[ref|tumu|tumu]] (base words) in te reo Māori that are used to form questions. These question words allow speakers to seek specific information about people, things, places, times, reasons, and methods. When asking for a piece of information using a [[ref|rerepātai|rerepaatai]] (question sentence) these words are used in the sentence in place of the piece of information you want to obtain and which word you use makes it clear what type of information you want to be supplied with. This includes the words: - [[word|wai|w-wai]]

* [[word|aha|w-aha]]

* [[word|hea|w-hea]]

* [[word|hia|w-hia]]

* [[word|pēhea|w-peehea]]

* [[word|tēhea|w-teehea]]/[[word|ēhea|w-eehea]]

examples.explanation: Uses "wai" (who) to ask about a person's name. Literally: "Who is your name?"
Uses "hea" with the locative particle "kei" to ask about location.
Uses "aha" to ask about a thing or situation.

examples.maori: I haere koe ki hea inanahi?
examples.explanation: Uses "hea" with the directional particle "ki" to ask about destination.
Uses "āhea" to ask about a future time.

content.shortDefinition: Particles used to indicate location in space or time.
content.categoryInfo: Part of the Particles (Punga) series
content.longDefinition: These particles are used with words which specific a location in space or time. This includes the words: i, hei, kei. Pūwāhi (locative particles) are a category of [[ref|punga|punga]] (particles) in te reo Māori that specify location in space or time. They typically appear before place names, location nouns, or time expressions to indicate where or when something happens. These includes the words: i, hei, kei.

examples.maori: I te whare karakia mātou i te Rātapu.
examples.english: We were at church on Sunday.
examples.explanation: The locative particle "i" indicates where we were in the past.
The locative particle "kei" combines with the interrogative "hea" to ask about present location.

examples.maori: Hei konei au e tatari ana ki a koe.
examples.english: I will be waiting for you here.
examples.explanation: The locative particle "hei" indicates where the speaker will be in the future.

examples.maori: Kei runga i te tēpu te pukapuka.
examples.english: The book is on the table.
examples.explanation: The locative particle "kei" combines with "runga" (on/above) and the preposition "i" to specify exact location.

content.shortDefinition: Particles that indicate the position or proximity of objects relative to the speaker and listener.

elements.content:
These are particles which add more context about the location of something, in particular often used to refer to whether something is near the speaker, near the listener, or distant from both. This includes the words: nei, nā and rā. These are often joined to other words, such as with the kupu (t)ēnei, (t)ēnā and (t)ērā. Pūhea (positional particles) are a distinctive class of [[ref|punga||punga]] (particles) in te reo Māori that indicate the position of objects in relation to the speaker and listener. They help to establish spatial relationships and often combine with other words to create demonstratives. In some grammars they are referred to as "[deictic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deixis) particles".

The three main positional particles in te reo Māori are:

1. **Nei** - Here/This - Indicates a position close to the speaker - Example: "tēnei whare" - "this house" (near me) - Can also appear after a noun: "te whare nei" - "this house"
2. **Nā** - There/That - Indicates a position close to the listener - Example: "tēnā whare" - "that house" (near you) - Can also appear after a noun: "te whare nā" - "that house"
3. **Rā** - Over there/That - Indicates a position distant from both speaker and listener - Example: "tērā whare" - "that house over there" (away from both of us) - Can also appear after a noun: "te whare rā" - "that house over there"

These positional particles are often combined with the definite article "te" to form the demonstratives tēnei/ēnei (this/these), tēnā/ēnā (that/those near you), and tērā/ērā (that/those over there).

The pattern changes when referring to plural items:

* "tēnei" (singular) becomes "ēnei" (plural)
* "tēnā" (singular) becomes "ēnā" (plural)
* "tērā" (singular) becomes "ērā" (plural)

Positional particles provide crucial spatial orientation and help to clarify which specific item is being referred to based on its location relative to the speaker and listener.

elements.maori: E noho ki tēnei tūru.
elements.explanation: The positional particle "nei" in "tēnei" indicates a chair close to the speaker.

elements.maori: Kei a koe tēnā pukapuka?
elements.explanation: The positional particle "nā" in "tēnā" indicates a book close to the listener.

elements.maori: Ko tērā te whare o Hone.
elements.explanation: The positional particle "rā" in "tērā" indicates a house distant from both speaker and listener.

content.shortDefinition: Particles that specify the identity, definiteness, or quantity of a noun.

elements.content: These are particles which precede noun phrases to indicate which thing is being referred to, specify whether we're talking about specific or general instances of that noun, as well as detail whether we're talking about singular or plural. These are referred to as "definitives" in some texts.

content.categoryInfo: Part of the Nominal Particles (Pūingoa) series

content.shortDefinition: Particles that show the relationship between a noun and other elements in a sentence.

elements.content: These are particles which describe the relationship between two things. This includes the words: ko, me, mā, mō, nā, nō, ki, i, kei, hei, a, o.

content.categoryInfo: Part of the Nominal Particles (Pūingoa) series

content.shortDefinition: Particles which introduce a noun, such as te, ngā, he and a.

elements.content:
## Pūtohu - Articles

These are particles which introduce a noun, such as te, ngā, he and a.

### *Pū Tautuhi - Definite Article*

The definite articles in te reo Māori are 'te' and 'ngā' which often specify that we're talking about a specific instance of the noun, as well as providing context on whether it is takitahi (singular) or takitini (plural).

* te ngeru (the cat)

* ngā ngeru (the cats)\\ While te/ngā are used for singular/plural, te can also be used to introduce a generic phrase which refers to the entire class of things it precedes, as in:

* Tekau heneti te utu mō te tamariki (The price for children is ten cents). ### *Pūnoa - Indefinite Article* * The indefinite article in te reo Māori is 'he' which doesn't specify any particular instance of the noun or provide any context about whether it is singular or plural.

* he ngeru (a cat, cats) ### ### *Pūmoko - Proper Article* * The proper article in te reo Māori is 'a' and indicates the word which follows it is a tūmoko (proper noun).

* a Mere

* a Josh

content.shortDefinition: Particles that indicate possession or ownership relationships.
content.categoryInfo: Part of the Particles (Punga) series
content.longDefinition: The possessive particles are tā, tō, ā, ō. These are used to specify the A/O category of the relationship between two things, as well as whether the possessum (the thing which is possessed) is singular or plural.

examples.maori: Ko tēnei te pukapuka ā Hemi.
examples.explanation: The possessive particle "ā" indicates A-category possession of the book by James (an acquired item).
The possessive particle "tō" combines with the pronoun "you" to form "your" in relation to mother (an O-category relationship).
The possessive particle "tō" indicates O-category possession (a house being in the O-category) with "rātou" (they/them) as the possessors.
The possessive particle and pronoun combine to form "aku" (my, plural possessum, A-category) in relation to keys (an acquired item).

content.shortDefinition: The verbal particle "ai" has a range of uses.

elements.maori: I ako au i te reo Māori i te kura. I reira i tūtaki ai au ki tōku hoa.
elements.english: I learned te reo Māori at school. That's where I met my friend.
elements.explanation: The "ai" in the second sentence refers back to "te kura" (the school) mentioned in the first sentence.

elements.maori: Ko te whare tēnei i noho ai mātou i tērā tau.
elements.english: This is the house where we lived last year.
elements.explanation: The "ai" indicates that "te whare" (the house) is the location of the action "noho" (live).

elements.maori: Ka haere au ki te mahi, ka whakareri ai i te kai.
elements.english: I go to work, then I prepare food.
elements.explanation: The "ai" indicates a sequence of habitual actions.

elements.maori: I hinga ia, i whara ai tōna ringaringa.
elements.english: He fell, (as a result) his arm was injured.
elements.explanation: The "ai" indicates that the injury was a result of the fall.

elements.maori: Kua reri te kai, kua taea ai e tātou te kai.
elements.english: The food is ready, (therefore) we can eat.
elements.explanation: The "ai" indicates that being able to eat is a result of the food being ready.

content.shortDefinition: A system for classifying relationships between possessor and possessed in te reo Māori.

elements.content:
The A/O categories (karangatanga a/o) represent a fundamental concept in te reo Māori that determines which possessive particles and possessive pronouns to use when describing relationships between things. This system is based on the nature of the relationship rather than the inherent properties of the objects themselves.

When expressing possession in te reo Māori, we must choose between:

* A-category possessives: ā, tā, mā, nā
* O-category possessives: ō, tō, mō, nō

The key principle behind this choice is not simply ownership but relates to:

* Control, dominance, and independence
* Direction of responsibility, obligation, and support
* Whether the possessor shelters, protects, guides, or leads the possessed

It's crucial to understand that the A/O distinction describes the relationship between things, not inherent properties of the objects themselves. The same object might belong to different categories depending on the relationship being described. ### Te karangatanga 'o' (O-category)

**This category generally includes:**

* The land, landmarks, mountains, rivers, and homes
* Types of shelter and sources of life
* One's whakapapa, ancestry, and lineage
* Those who care for you (parents, teachers, leaders)
* People in the same generation or above
* All types of friends (using the word "hoa")
* Clothing, accessories, and adornments
* Body parts, including mind and figurative heart
* Thoughts, memories, knowledge
* Feelings and emotions
* Inherent qualities ### Te karangatanga 'a' (A-category) **This category generally includes:**

* Those with less authority or lower in hierarchy than you
* Romantic partners (except when using "hoa")
* Animals (except horses used as transport), birds, fish
* Trees and plants
* Food and drink (except fresh water and medicine)
* Actions, activities, jobs, and work
* Tools, equipment, and human-made items

Context is key in determining the appropriate category. For example, a house might be in the O-category when describing it as shelter for yourself, but in the A-category when referring to it as something you built for someone else.

elements.maori: Tōku whare
elements.explanation: Houses are typically in the O-category as they shelter and protect us.

elements.maori: Tāku kurī
elements.explanation: Animals are typically in the A-category.

elements.maori: Ō mātou mātua
elements.explanation: Parents are in the O-category as they care for, shelter, and guide children.

elements.maori: Ā rātou tamariki
elements.explanation: Children are in the A-category in relation to their parents, who have authority over them.

elements.maori: Te tuhinga a Hēmi i tana reta
elements.explanation: Actions from transitive verbs in active voice use the A-category.

content.shortDefinition: A group of related words that function as a unit within a sentence in te reo Māori.

elements.content:
The phrase is the essential unit of both grammar and speech in te reo Māori.

It can be considered to have three sections, a central section called the nucleus which is surrounded on either side by the preposed periphery and the postposed periphery. The nucleus can only contain bases (content words such as verbs and nouns) while the peripheries can only contain particles (words with grammatical functions that add extra context and structure).

All base words have an English translation, but that is not true of all particles, some of which can be roughly compared to English words like "at" or "to" but many of which do not make sense to translate and must be understood in terms of their structural function.

parts.annotation: directional particle indicating movement towards speaker

elements.content:
Although the nucleus of a phrase can contain multiple base words, there is always a single base word which provides the central meaning to the phrase. This word is called the head and influences how we categorise what type of phrase it is.

* [[ref\|Noun Phrases\|kiianga-tuuingoa]] contain nouns as the base and are introduced with determiners.
* [[ref\|Verb Phrases\|kiianga-tuumahi]] contain verbs as the base and are introduced with verbal particles.

For the most part, these notes attempt to align with the taxonomy used in [[resource\|Te Reo Māori: The Basics Explained\|resource-9780947506698]] as the author of these notes prefers that classification. In that text, David Kārena-Holmes recognises only noun and verb phrases, however we will also be using some other classes of phrase imported from other grammars:

* [[ref\|Prepositional Phrases\|kiianga-puuhono]] are any phrase which starts with a preposition.
* [[ref\|Connective Phrases\|kiianga-hono]] are used to link two ideas together.
* [[ref\|Comparative Phrases\|kiianga-whakatairite]] are used to describe the difference between two things.

content.categoryInfo: Part of the Sentence Structure (Hanganga Rerenga) series

content.shortDefinition: Complete grammatical units of speech or writing.

elements.content:
A sentence is a complete unit of communication. Functionally, it is an utterance that contains at least one [[ref\|Predicate\|predicate-subject-comment]](the main statement or action). It can consist of a single [[ref\|clause\|aho]] in the case of a Simple Sentence or {{reremāmā}} which generally expresses one idea, or multiple clauses in the case of a Complex Sentence or {{rerepūhui}} to link together several related pieces of information.

An example of a simple sentence might be: {{he kaiako ia}} (he/she is a teacher)

An example of a complex sentence might be: {{kia oti te mahi, ka hoki tātou}} (when the work is done, we will go home)

There are a number of other sentence related words that you might come across in your study:

* A {{rerehāoho}} is an Active Sentence, a sentence which uses the active [[ref\|voice\|reo]] or {{reo hāoho}}. This is a sentence where the agent is the subject of the sentence as in "Sarah threw the ball."
* A {{rerehāngū}} is a [[ref\|Passive Sentence\|rerehaanguu]], a sentence which uses the passive [[ref\|voice\|reo]] or {{reo hāngū}}. This is a sentence where the subject of the sentence is the receiver of the action as in "the ball was thrown by Sarah".
* You might see {{reremahi}} used to describe verbal sentences focused on describing actions and {{reremahi āhua}} to describe sentences focused on using stative verbs to describe states of being.

content.categoryInfo: Part of the Sentence Structure (Hanganga Rerenga) series

content.shortDefinition: Demonstrative determiners communicate location or position relative to the speaker and listener

elements.content:
Demonstrative [[ref|determiners|pumau]] play a vital role in indicating location or position relative to the speaker and listener, helping to specify which object or entity is being referred to in discourse.

## Position Definitives

| Singular | Plural | Meaning |
| --- | --- | --- |
| tēnei | ēnei | this/these (near the speaker) |
| tēnā | ēnā | that/those (near the listener) |
| tērā | ērā | that/those (distant from both) |

These position definitives specify the location of objects relative to the conversation participants.

### Structure of Position Definitives

Position definitives are composed of two elements:

1. **[[ref|Pū tautuhi|putohu]]** (definite article): "te"

2. **[[ref|Pūhea|puuhea]]** (positional particle): "nei"/"nā"/"rā"

These components can be used together as a single word (tēnei, tēnā, tērā) or separated to surround a noun:

* te [noun] nei (singular, near speaker)

* te [noun] nā (singular, near listener)

* te [noun] rā (singular, distant)

* ngā [noun] nei (plural, near speaker)

* ngā [noun] nā (plural, near listener)

* ngā [noun] rā (plural, distant)

Example of both forms used in a sentence: *Ka mihi atu ki a koutou katoa, e tautoko ana i te kaupapa nei, i tēnei pō.* "Greetings to all of you who are supporting this purpose/initiative, on this night."

## **Reference Definitives**

**[T]aua** is a special demonstrative that refers to something already established in context. Unlike other demonstratives, it must be paired with a noun to function properly:

* taua āporo (that apple I mentioned earlier)

* aua pene (those pens we were talking about)

It serves as an <a target="*blank" rel="noopener noreferrer nofollow" class="editor-link" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anaphora*(linguistics)">anaphoric </a>reference to previously mentioned topics.

## Specifying Definitives

**[T]ētahi** functions as an indefinite determiner meaning "a," "some," or "certain ones." It can introduce a previously unmentioned entity or refer to a subset of a larger group:

*I rongo rātau i tētahi iwi e kōrerorero ana i roto o te kohu o te maunga.* "They heard some people talking from within the mist on the mountain."

elements.content:
Clauses are made up of a predicate phrase, a subject phrase and any comment phrases. However, a sentence can be made up of multiple clauses. The [[ref\|aho motuhake\|aho-motuhake]] (main clause) contains the principal statement of the sentence. The [[ref\|aho whakawhirinaki\|aho-whakawhirinaki]] (subordinate clause/dependent clause) is any other clause in the sentence that supports or expands on the aho motuhake (main clause).

In the sentence {{Kei te pirangi a Mere kia mutu te patu i ngā wēra}} (Mere wants the killing of whales to stop) the main clause is {{Kei te pirangi a Mere}} and the subordinate clause is {{kia mutu te patu i ngā wēra}}. The sentence is primarily about the fact that Mere wants something and the additional clause expands on what that is.

elements.content:
Command sentences give a direction or instruction to someone. The structure of the command depends on the type of base word being used.

If the base word is an [[ref\|Intransitive Verbs\|tuumahi-poro]], the command is structured with the verb as the nucleus of the first phrase. If the verb and any particles in the phrase (other than rā which is not counted) is longer than two [[ref\|morae\|mora]], the phrase is introduced with [[ref\|e\|puumahi_e]].

elements.maori: E tū!
elements.explanation: Command using "e" with a short verb "tū" (stand).

elements.explanation: The word {{haere}} is longer than two morae, so it is used without a verbal particle.

elements.content: If the base word is a [[ref\|Transitive Verbs\|tuumahi-whiti]] and no direct object is specified, the command can be structured the same as a command with an intransitive verb:

elements.content:
These are particles which add more context about the direction being referred to. This includes the words: i, ki, mai, atu * mai towards the subject or speaker * atu away from the subject or speaker * ake up from the subject or speaker * ihodown from the subject or speaker ## Directional Particles (Pūanga)

Pūanga (directional particles) are a specialized type of particle in te reo Māori that indicate the direction of movement or action. These particles provide crucial information about the spatial or temporal relationship between the action, the speaker, and other referents in the discourse.

The main directional particles in te reo Māori are:

1. **Mai** - Towards - Indicates movement or action directed towards the speaker or the subject
2. **Atu** - Away - Indicates movement or action directed away from the speaker or the subject
3. **Ake** - Upwards - Indicates movement or action in an upward direction from the subject. Can also indicate action in a future time
4. **Iho** - Downwards - Indicates movement or action in a downward direction from the subject. Can also indicate action in a past time

These directional particles often follow verbs to specify the direction of the action, and they can combine with other particles to create more specific meanings. They play a significant role in spatial orientation within te reo Māori discourse.

The directional particles "mai" and "atu" are particularly common and important for distinguishing whether an action is moving towards or away from the speaker or another reference point.

elements.explanation: The directional particle "mai" (within "homai") indicates movement towards the speaker.

elements.maori: Haere atu ki te kura.
elements.explanation: The directional particle "atu" indicates movement away from the speaker.

elements.content:
A basic identity or 'ko' sentence states that the first phrase of the sentence and the second phrase of the sentence are equal or the same thing.

"\[Ko Josh\] \[ahau\]" is saying that "Josh" and "Me" refer to the same thing.

"\[Ko Mere\] \[tāku hoa\]" is saying that "Mere" and "my friend" are both labels that apply to the same person.

"\[Ko koe\] \[te tangata tika\]" is saying that "you" and "the right person" are the same. A basic 'ko' sentence is made up of two phrases. The first phrase is one of:

* Ko \[personal name or place name\] - Ko Mere

* Ko \[pronoun\] - Ko koe

* Ko \[definitive\] \[noun\] - Ko te waka

* Ko \[t-class definitive\] - Ko (t)ēnei

The second phrase is one of:

* \[definitive\] \[noun\] - te wā

* \[t-class definitive\] - (t)ēnā

A classification or 'he' sentence says "this thing belongs to this group of things."

"\[He pene\] \[tēnei\]" says that "this" belongs to the group of things called "pen".\
"\[He kaiako\] \[ia\]" says that "he/she/they" belong to the class of people called 'kaiako'.\
"\[He wairua aroha\] \[tōna\]" says that "her \[spirit\]" belongs to the set/group "spirits that are loving" as in if you made a list of all the loving spirits, hers would be included. We can say tōna on its own as "spirit" is introduced and implied by the first part of the sentence.

Notes on the structure of a 'he' sentence are covered when we dig into this format in more depths in [Kōnae Ako 8](#heading=h.h4790whiv6cm). We [previously covered](#heading=h.qftf434x7vvz) these in Kōnae Ako 3: Wahi with examples like "He aha tēnei? He pene tēnā."\
A basic 'he' sentence is made up of two phrases. The first phrase is one of:

* He \[noun\] - He nēhi
* He \[noun\] \[adjective\] - He ngakau aroha
* He \[adjective\] - He wera

The second phrase is one of:

* a \[personal name or place name\]
* \[pronoun\] - ia.
* \[definitive\] \[noun\] - (t)ōna wairua.
* \[t-class definitive\] - (t)ēnā.

A 'he' sentence can be future tense by using 'hei' (although this is considered different to other uses of the kupu 'hei' - they are homophonous but distinct):

* Hei kaiako ia - She is going to be a teacher.

### **I**n this section we use both classifying 'he' sentences and [existential possessives](#heading=h.t2i7vm3l2trz).

Despite appearing similarly, they are considered to be different sentence types with subtly different properties. In some cases it's a little confusing about which type of sentence is which.\
'He kaiako ia' is a classifying sentence. 'He waewae roa tōna.' is an existential possessive.

We're using this construction in class and for aromatawai, but it should be noted that we could also rearrange the phrases in these sentences like so:\
\[He waha nui\] \[tōna\] - He has a big mouth (Existential possessive sentence)\
\[He nui\] \[tōna waha\] - He has a big mouth (His mouth \[explicit\] belongs to the group of all things that are big.)

Similarly:\
\[He pai rawa atu\] \[tāu mahi\] - Your work is very good (Your work belongs to the group of all things that are very good.)\
\[He mahi pai rawa atu\] \[tāu\] - Your work is very good. (Existential possessive sentence)

\[He ngakau māhaki\] \[tōna\]. (Existential possessive sentence)\
\[He māhaki\] \[tōna ngakau\] - Their heart belongs to the group of all things that are humble.

Kei is a location particle (or introductory preposition) which introduces a locational sentence. These sentences locate objects or events in place or in time.

Kei te kura ia. - She is at school.

Kei a Hone taku koti. - John has my coat (temporary possession).

\[I raro i te tēpu\] \[tō pukapuka\] - Your book was under the table.

\[A te Rāhina\] \[te hui\] - The hui is on Monday (future).

\[Āpōpō\] \[te hui\] - The gathering is tomorrow (sometimes the locational preposition can be omitted if the word incorporates the preposition as in **ā**pōpō, **i**napō or **i**nāianei).

The location particles include:\
present: kei\
past: i\
future: kei, hei (hei is not used in basic sentences but has a more complicated use in sentences which give a strong sense of future intention or time) (Reed: kei/hei/ko are regional variants here with ko being spatial only), a (a is only used for temporal location, not spatial).

If the predicate phrase is complex (for example, contains modifiers) the word order is commonly changed:

\[I raro i te tēpu\] 	\[tō pukapuka\]

\[Predicate\]	\[Subject\]

Becomes:\
\[I raro\] \[tō pukapuka\] 	\[i te tēpu\]

\[Predicate\]	\[Subject\]	\[Predicate continued\]

Similarly:\
\[Kei te marae o Te Herenga Waka\] 	\[ia\]

\[Predicate\] \[Subject\]

Becomes:

\[Kei te marae\]	\[ia\]		\[o Te Herenga Waka\]\
\[Predicate\]	\[Subject\]	\[Predicate continued\]

\
Some of our farewells, 'hei konā' and 'hei konei rā' are examples of this type of sentence using the locatives 'konei' and 'konā'.

Sometimes called Conjunctive Phrases, these are small phrases used to join two thoughts or ideas. They often function as interjections containing idioms.

Examples include:

* {{... me te mea nei …}} (as if, it looks as if, it would seem, it looks as though, it's as if, it's as though.)
* {{... i tua atu i tērā …}} (apart from that)
* {{… nō reira …}} (therefore, thereby, that's why, so, consequently, for that reason, hence, thus, accordingly)
* {{... ka mutu …}} (and also, and furthermore, as well as that, and what's more)
* {{... heoi anō …}} (so much for that, there is no more, there is none other, and so, well! so so, but, however, that's all, all that had to be done was, it was OK, pretty good, all one has to do is)

elements.content:
In te reo Māori, words generally fall into the category of being either [[ref\|Base Words\|tumu]] or [[ref\|Particles\|punga]]. There are a number of different ways to think about the differences between these words. Conceptually, base words describe things that are part of our experience: objects in the world, emotions, actions that can be taken. In contrast, particles are the "little words" that provide structure to sentences.

Grammatically, base words are words which occupy the nucleus of a [[ref\|Phrase\|kiianga]] while particles are the words which occupy the peripheries.

Different authors of grammar textbooks take different approaches to cataloguing the behaviours of words. This resource will not align perfectly with any specific text on the subject, but will pick and choose from a variety of sources. In particular, it will take the following positions:

* Te reo Māori does not have a word class for [[ref\|Adjectives\|tuahua]]. It has sub-classes of nouns and verbs which can be used in a similar way to how adjectives are used in English but which are not a distinct adjective class.
* There are a number of words with the same spelling and pronunciation. In many cases they have related meanings. One example is the word [[word\|kai\|w-kai]]. {{Kai}} can be used as a verb meaning "to eat" but it can also be used as a noun meaning "food". Additionally, there is a verbal particle {{kai}} which is a variant of {{kei}} used in some dialects. Some authors take the view that some verbs can be used as nouns (or vice-versa). Others take the view that words such as {{kai}} belong to a "universals" class of words with multiple functions. This resource will take the position that {{kai}} (noun), {{kai}} (verb) and {{kai}} (verbal particle) are all separate words, even though some of their meanings are related.

Harlow (2001) says:

> Further, there are a number of cases of **homophony**, pairs of words which are identical in form, but which have different, though often related, meanings and belong to different parts of speech. For example, *patu* meaning 'strike, kill' is a verb, but *patu* 'kind of weapon, club' is a noun; *kai* 'eat' is a verb, *kai* 'food' is a noun.
